item.title: House Tax Bill Draft Calls for $30,000 SALT Deduction Limit
item.description: The House tax committee’s draft bill to renew President Donald Trump’s tax cuts calls for increasing the state and local tax deduction to $30,000 for couples, but limits the write-off to households earning $400,000 or less, according to a person familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC.

item.title: Fed’s Kugler Sees Significant Tariff Impact Despite Recent News
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Adriana Kugler said the Trump administration’s tariff policies are likely to boost inflation and weigh on economic growth, even with the recently announced reduction in levies on China.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Adriana Kugler

item.title: Americans Hit the Road as Economic Fears Discourage Flying
item.description: Kristin Herman and her partner had been planning a European getaway with stops in Paris and Rome, but with the US economy suddenly wobbling, the couple instead drove to Oregon’s nearby redwood forests and Cannon Beach — even camping some nights to save on hotels.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Nathan Risser

media:content.media:description: Traffic moves along Interstate 80 in Emeryville, California, US, on Wednesday, Nov. 27, 2024. AAA projects 79.9 million travelers will head 50 miles or more from home over the Thanksgiving holiday travel period. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: Senegal Seeks to Woo $1.7 Billion Investment for Digital Economy
item.description: Senegalese President Bassirou Diomaye Faye seeks to attract $1.7 billion of investments to build digital infrastructure and create more job opportunities for the country’s youth.
item.dc:creator: Yinka Ibukun

media:content.media:description: Bassirou Diomaye Faye, Senegal’s president, speaks during his inauguration ceremony in Diamniadio, Senegal, on Tuesday, April 2, 2024. Senegal’s opposition politician Faye was sworn in as president on Tuesday, becoming the youngest elected African leader less than three weeks after he was released from prison to run in the election last month.

item.title: Traders See Fed Cutting Rates Just Twice in 2025 on Cooling Trade War
item.description: Traders lowered their bets on the Federal Reserve’s interest-rate cuts this year, pricing in just two reductions for 2025 after the US and China agreed to cut tariffs and moderate their trade war.
item.dc:creator: Michael Mackenzie

item.title: US Said to Welcome EU Proposal to Cooperate on Economic Security
item.description: The US has welcomed European Union proposals to cooperate on mutual investments and economic security challenges, while continuing to provide little clarity on the possible outcomes of trade negotiations between the two sides, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Employees work on a VW Golf on the assembly line at the Volkswagen AG factory in Wolfsburg, Germany, on Thursday, May 23, 2024. Auto sales in Europe rose 12% in April as manufacturers including Volkswagen AG and Renault SA benefited from robust demand for plug-in and conventional cars in several major markets.

item.title: Detained Duterte Set for Mayoral Win Ahead of ICC Trial in Hague
item.description: Ex-Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is leading in the local election in his clan’s stronghold south of the country, even as he awaits trial in the Netherlands for alleged crimes against humanity.
item.dc:creator: Andreo Calonzo

media:content.media:description: Rodrigo Duterte during a campaign rally in Hong Kong on March 9, days before his arrest. Photo by Anthony Kwan/Getty Images

item.title: Romanian Bond Sale Lures Investors After Yield Jump as Leu Gains
item.description: Romania managed to attract solid demand in a domestic bond sale but the funding came at an increased price as political risks before the presidential run-off continued to weigh on investors’ perception.
item.dc:creator: Peter Laca, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: The parliament building during parliamentary elections, in Bucharest, Romania, on Sunday, Dec. 1, 2024. In the final days before Romania’s parliamentary elections this weekend, the governing parties’ leaders both quit, pollsters gave up on projecting the results and the nation’s top court cast serious doubt on the integrity of the voting process.

item.title: UK and EU Haggle Over Fish and Food Days Before Reset Summit
item.description: Britain and the European Union are still trying to resolve disagreements over fisheries and food checks just a week before a summit in London where Prime Minister Keir Starmer plans to announce a major reset in post-Brexit relations.
item.dc:creator: Alex Wickham, Jorge Valero, Alberto Nardelli

media:content.media:description: Fishermen in the English Channel from the Port of Newhaven.

item.title: The Recession Chatter Is Getting Louder. Watch These Metrics
item.description: We’ve built a dashboard to help you figure out if we’re headed for a downturn.
item.dc:creator: Reade Pickert, Mark Glassman

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump with his “reciprocal tariffs” chart during an event in the White House Rose Garden on April 2.

item.title: France’s Lombard Wants Broader Tariff Disarmament After US-China Trade-War Reprieve
item.description: French Finance Minister Eric Lombard welcomed the 90-day hiatus in the US-China trade war, but said more efforts are needed to de-escalate global tariff tensions.
item.dc:creator: William Horobin, Kamil Kowalcze, Alessandra Migliaccio, Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Eric Lombard, France's finance minister, at the EU Ministers for Economic and Financial Affairs (ECOFIN) and Central Bank Governors informal meeting in Warsaw, Poland, on Friday, April 11, 2025. Europe’s decision to ramp up defense spending after years of neglect is the right choice, according to European Union finance ministers. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: US, China to Slash Tariffs During 90-Day Reprieve for Talks
item.description: The US and China will temporarily lower tariffs on each other’s products in a dramatic ratcheting down of trade tensions that buys the world’s two largest economies three months to work toward a broader agreement.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, right, and US trade representative Jamieson Greer in Geneva on May 12. Photographer: Fabrice Coffrini/Getty Images

item.title: Codelco Would Keep More Profits If Carolina Toha Wins the Presidency in Chile
item.description: Top copper miner Codelco would be able to retain more profit to help dig itself out of debt and overhaul its aging deposits if Carolina Toha wins this year’s presidential election in Chile, according to her economic spokesperson.
item.dc:creator: Carolina Gonzalez, Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Carolina Toha speaks after registering her presidential candidacy

item.title: Consumer Confidence Rises in Canada After Carney’s Election Win
item.description: Canadians are growing more optimistic about the economy, as the conclusion of a national election relieves some anxiety around the country’s direction and US President Donald Trump’s threats.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: The Port of Saint John in St. John, New Brunswick, Canada, on Tuesday, May 6, 2025. The city is the most vulnerable in Canada to trade friction with the US because of its reliance on the American market for oil, lumber and seafood exports, according to data released in February by the Canadian Chamber of Commerce, CTV news reports.

item.title: Hungary Freezes Some Spending After Budget Gap Hits $8 Billion
item.description: Hungary’s government deficit rose to a record through April as interest payments outpaced tax income growth, leading the government to announce a spending freeze in parts of the budget.
item.dc:creator: Marton Kasnyik

media:content.media:description: Viktor Orban

item.title: The Polite Ways Companies Say Trump Tariffs Hurt
item.description: One of the remarkable things emerging from President Donald Trump’s tariff wars is a rebirth of the art of the polite slight. Or the “thanks but no thanks, sir” in the coded messages companies and industry lobbyists are putting out in public statements and submissions to government requests for comment about forthcoming tariffs. Dive into some and ignore your modern surroundings and you could be forgiven for thinking you are reading historical letters layered in ceremony, protocol and plenty of
item.dc:creator: Shawn Donnan

item.title: Low-Income US Families Face Growing Gap Between Earnings, Costs
item.description: There’s a growing gap between what low-income families earn and what it actually costs to live in the US, according to a new study that says headline measures of inflation fail to capture the burden on these households.
item.dc:creator: Jarrell Dillard, Nazmul Ahasan

item.title: Greece Wants to Repay Bailout Loans 10 Years Ahead of Time
item.description: Greece plans to repay loans from its first bailout program 10 years ahead of schedule, Finance Minister Kyriakos Pierrakakis said, a move that’s set to ease the country’s debt burden in the future.
item.dc:creator: Sotiris Nikas, Paul Tugwell, Oliver Crook

item.title: BOE’s Lombardelli Voted to Cut Rates as ‘Insurance’ Against Trade Wars
item.description: Bank of England Deputy Governor Clare Lombardelli said growth in UK wages and services prices is still too high to be consistent with bringing inflation back to the 2% target but she voted to cut interest rates last week to provide “insurance” against the risk of an economic slowdown caused by global trade wars.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Clare Lombardelli Photographer: Jaimi Joy/Bloomberg

item.title: IMF Plans Kenya Debt Scrutiny to Weigh Funding Needs in New Deal
item.description: The International Monetary Fund plans an in-depth review of Kenya’s debt to determine the nation’s financing needs under a new program.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: IMF branding.

item.title: ECB to Cut by More as Inflation Undershoots 2%, Poll Shows
item.description: The European Central Bank will lower borrowing costs more than previously expected this year to below 2% as inflation is seen undershooting the institution’s target in early 2026, according to economists surveyed by Bloomberg.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: Philip Diehl on the Booming Business of Gold Coins
item.description: Why people crave physical gold.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: One-ounce Britannia gold coins at Gold Investments Ltd. bullion dealers arranged in London, UK, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. Gold retreated on Thursday, after notching its latest record, after President Donald Trump triggered tumult on global markets with sweeping “reciprocal” tariffs.

item.title: SNB’s Brief Era of Positive Rates May Be About to End
item.description: The Swiss National Bank will probably cut its interest rate to zero in June after less than three years in positive territory, according to a Bloomberg survey.
item.dc:creator: Bastian Benrath-Wright, Harumi Ichikura

item.title: Global Stocks Climb After US, China Agree to Cut Tariffs for 90 Days
Japan’s Merchants’ Mood Hits Worst in Three Years on Tariff Woes
item.description: Sentiment among Japanese merchants sank to the lowest in more than three years, underscoring deepening concerns over the economic outlook at home and abroad as the impact from US tariffs begins to filter into the economy.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

media:content.media:description: Cherry trees in bloom in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, April 4, 2025. Japan's cabinet office will release a monthly consumer confidence survey on April 9.

item.title: US and China Tout Progress in Trade Talks, Offer Few Details
item.description: The US and China both reported “substantial progress” after two days of talks in Switzerland aimed at de-escalating a trade war, marking what Chinese Vice Premier He Lifeng called “an important first step” toward resolving differences.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Leonard, Hugo Miller

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, left, and Jamieson Greer after talks between US and Chinese officials in Geneva on May 11.

item.title: Swedes’ Housing Optimism Weakens With Lower Consumer Confidence
item.description: Optimism among Swedes over the direction of home prices is waning as the Nordic country continues to grapple with economic headwinds and the prospect of slowing growth.
item.dc:creator: Charles Daly

item.title: Africa’s Eswatini Kingdom Plans $275 Million Wealth Fund
item.description: The southern African Kingdom of Eswatini plans to start a sovereign wealth fund of around 5 billion emalangeni ($275 million) this year to help channel money into areas including manufacturing and agriculture, its finance minister said.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek
